questions.question_text: A new multicast server is being added to an existing PIM Sparse mode network. Which device in this network must the new server register with before its multicast traffic can be dispersed throughout the network?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
Key points for this this question are:
the server is a multicast SOURCE
PIM Sparse mode networks use a Rendezvous Point (RP)
RP's are aware of the hosts that are interest in receiving the multicast traffic source from the Server.
"Sources register with the RP and then data is forwarded down the shared tree to the receivers"

IF the question asked about the multicast RECEIVER:
a multicast receiver sends a IGMP membership report to the local PIM Router
The local PIM router/last hop router will send a join request in the direction of the RP, so that a distribution tree can be built for the traffic the client is interested in receiving.

D
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipmulti_pim/configuration/xe-16/imc-pim-xe-16-book/imc-tech-oview.html
When hosts join a multicast group, the directly connected routers send PIM Join messages toward the RP.

Selected Answer: D
provided answer is correct

comments.content:

cisco_R3#show running-config | section access
...
ip access-list extended Q_648
 deny tcp any any eq telnet
 permit tcp any any range ftp-data pop3

discussion.content:
D. looks good but cisco IOS swapped numbers to port names:
Extended IP access list Q_648
 20 deny tcp any any eq telnet
 40 permit tcp any any range ftp-data pop3
==
original cmd:
cisco(config-ext-nacl)#40 permit tcp any any range 20 110

comments.content: The question doesn't specifically refer to a policy-map, just says policy.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct, for the policy map to MATCH an entry we should use 'permit' otherwise use 'deny'.

questions.question_text: You want to create a policy that allows all TCP traffic in the port range of 20 to 110, except for telnet traffic, which should be dropped. Which of the following access control lists will accomplish this?

choices.D:
deny tcp any any eq 23
permit tcp any any range 20 110
choices.A:
deny tcp any any eq 22
permit tcp any any gt 20 lt 110
choices.C:
deny tcp any any eq 23
permit tcp any any
choices.B:
permit tcp any any range 22 443
deny tcp any any eq 23

discussion.content:
Edge Node Design:
In SD-Access, fabric edge nodes represent the access layer in a two or three-tier hierarchy. The access layer is the edge of the campus. It is the place where end devices attach to the wired portion of the campus network. The edge nodes also represent the place where devices that extend the network connectivity out one more layer connect. These include devices such as IP phones, access points, and extended nodes.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
Answer shown is correct.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/solutions/CVD/Campus/cisco-sda-design-guide.html

questions.question_text: In a Cisco SD-Access network architecture, what is the role of the Fabric Edge Node?

choices.B: It connects external layer 3 networks to the SDA fabric
choices.D: It connects wireless endpoints to the SDA fabric
choices.A: It manages endpoint to device relationships
choices.C: It connects wired endpoints to the SDA fabric

questions.question_text: What are two benefits of virtualizing the server with the use of VMs in a data center environment? (Choose two.)

choices.E: reduced IP and MAC address requirements
choices.A: reduced rack space, power, and cooling requirements

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
A & D are correct

Selected Answer: AD
A + D are correct

Selected Answer: AD
voting. provided answer is correct
you can have a brand new server up and working in under 3 minutes with Azure , AWS and GCP
Virtualizing the environment does reduce rack space and cooling as its stored in the cloud provider datacentre
The given answer is correct

Selected Answer: CD
C and D are correct
C and D are correct

A. Network Address Translation (NAT): This feature is not exclusive to NextGen firewalls. Traditional firewalls commonly incorporate NAT functionalities.

B. Secure remote access VPN (RA VPN): Similarly, this is not exclusive to NextGen firewalls. Both traditional and NextGen firewalls can offer secure remote access VPN capabilities.

C. Deep packet inspection: NextGen firewalls often excel in deep packet inspection, allowing them to analyze and understand the contents of packets beyond the traditional packet header information.

D. Reputation-based malware detection: NextGen firewalls typically employ more advanced methods like reputation-based detection to identify and block malicious activities.

E. IPSec site-to-site VPN: Again, like RA VPN, this is not exclusive to NextGen firewalls. Both traditional and NextGen firewalls can support IPSec site-to-site VPNs.


Deep packet inspection
Reputation-based malware detection

Selected Answer: CD
